A. |year=2004 |title=Creativity |journal=Annual Review of Psychology |volume=55 |pages=657–687 |doi=10.1146/annurev.psych.55.090902.141502 |pmid=14744230}} * [[Sabaneev, Leonid]]. The Psychology of the Musico-Creative Process // Psyche. - Vol. 9 (July 1928). - pp. 37–54. * {{cite journal |author1=Smith, S. M. |author2=Blakenship, S.E. |date=1 April 1991 |journal=American Journal of Psychology |title=Incubation and the persistence of fixation in problem solving |volume=104 |pages=61–87 |doi=10.2307/1422851 |issn=0002-9556 |issue=1 |pmid=2058758 |jstor=1422851}} * {{cite book |author=Taylor, C. W. |chapter=Various approaches to and definitions of creativity |editor= Sternberg, R. J. |title=The nature of creativity: Contemporary psychological perspectives |year=1988 |publisher=Cambridge University Press}} * {{cite book |author=Torrance, E. P. |title=Torrance Tests of Creative Thinking |year=1974 |publisher=Personnel Press |authorlink=Ellis Paul Torrance}} * [[Marie-Louise von Franz|von Franz, Marie-Louise]], ''Psyche and Matter'' (Shambhala, 1992) {{ISBN|0-87773-902-1}} * {{cite journal | doi = 10.1002/cne.903260405 |author1=Andersen B. |author2=Korbo L. |author3=Pakkenberg B. | year = 1992 | title = A quantitative study of the human cerebellum with unbiased stereological techniques | url = | journal = The Journal of Comparative Neurology | volume = 326 | issue = 4| pages = 549–560 | pmid = 1484123 }} * {{cite journal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0835746100 |author1=Imamizu H. |author2=Kuroda T. |author3=Miyauchi S. |author4=Yoshioka T. |author5=Kawato M. | year = 2003 | title = Modular organization of internal models of tools in the cerebellum | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 100 | issue = 9| pages = 5461–5466 | pmid=12704240 | pmc=154367}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Jung-Beeman | first1 = M. | last2 = Bowden | first2 = E. | last3 = Haberman | first3 = J. | last4 = Frymiare | first4 = J. | last5 = Arambel-Liu | first5 = S. | last6 = Greenblatt | first6 = R. | last7 = Reber | first7 = P. | last8 = Kounios | first8 = J. | year = 2004 | title = Neural activity when people solve verbal problems with insight | doi = 10.1371/journal.pbio.0020097 | pmid = 15094802 | pmc = 387268 | journal = PLOS Biology | volume = 2 | issue = 4| pages = 500–510 }} * {{cite journal |author1=Miller E. |author2=Cohen J. | year = 2001 | title = An integrative theory of prefrontal cortex function | url = | journal = Annual Review of Neuroscience | volume = 24 | issue = | pages = 167–202 | pmid = 11283309 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.neuro.24.1.167 }} * Miyake, A., & Shah, P. (Eds.). (1999). Models of working memory: Mechanisms of active maintenance and executive control. New York: Cambridge University Press. * Schmahmann, J. (Ed.). (1997). The cerebellum and cognition. New York: Academic Press. * {{cite journal | author = Schmahmann J | year = 2004 | title = Disorders of the cerebellum: Ataxia, dysmetria of thought, and the cerebellar cognitive affective syndrome | url = | journal = Journal of Neuropsychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience | volume = 16 | issue = 3| pages = 367–378 | doi=10.1176/appi.neuropsych.16.3.367 | pmid=15377747}} * Sullivan, Ceri and Graeme Harper, ed., ''The Creative Environment: Authors at Work'' (Cambridge: English Association/Boydell and Brewer, 2009) * {{cite journal | last1 = Vandervert | first1 = L | year = 2003a | title = How working memory and cognitive modeling functions of the cerebellum contribute to discoveries in mathematics | url = | journal = New Ideas in Psychology | volume = 21 | issue = 2| pages = 159–175 | doi=10.1016/s0732-118x(03)00012-6}} * Vandervert, L. (2003b). The neurophysiological basis of innovation. In L. V. Shavinina (Ed.) The international handbook on innovation (pp. 17–30). Oxford, England: Elsevier Science. * {{cite journal | last1 = Vandervert | first1 = L | year = 2011 | title = The evolution of language: The cerebro-cerebellar blending of visual-spatial working memory with vocalizations | url = | journal = The Journal of Mind and Behavior | volume = 32 | issue = | pages = 317–334 }} * Vandervert, L. (in press). How the blending of cerebellar internal models can explain the evolution of thought and language. Cerebellum. * {{cite journal | last1 = Vandervert | first1 = L. | last2 = Schimpf | first2 = P. | last3 = Liu | first3 = H. | year = 2007 | title = How working memory and the cerebellum collaborate to produce creativity and innovation [Special Issue] | url = | journal = Creativity Research Journal | volume = 19 | issue = 1| pages = 1–19 | doi=10.1080/10400410709336873}} * Vandervert, L., & Vandervert-Weathers, K. (in press). New brain-imaging studies indicate how prototyping is related to entrepreneurial giftedness and innovation education in children. In L. Shavinina (Ed.), The International Handbook of Innovation Education. London: Routlage. * {{cite book |author=DeGraff, J. |author2=Lawrence, K. |year=2002 |title=Creativity at Work |publisher=Jossey-Bass |isbn=978-0-7879-5725-4}} * Gielen, P. (2013). Creativity and other Fundamentalisms. Mondriaan: Amsterdam. {{Refend}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |title=Creativity and Taoism, A Study of Chinese Philosophy, Art, and Poetry|last=Chung-yuan |first=Chang |date=1970 | publisher=Harper Torchbooks |location=New York|isbn=978-0-06-131968-6}} * {{cite book |title=The Dark Side of Creativity |editor1-last=Cropley |editor1-first=David H. |editor2-last=Cropley |editor2-first=Arthur J. |editor3-last=Kaufman |editor3-first=James C. |editor4-last=Runco |editor4-first=Mark A.| display-editors = 3 |year=2010 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |isbn=978-0-521-13960-1 |laysummary=http://www.cambridge.org/gb/knowledge/isbn/item2704083/?site_locale=en_GB |laydate=24 November 2010 |ref=harv }} * {{cite book |title=Sudden Genius?: The Gradual Path to Creative Breakthroughs |last=Robinson |first=Andrew |year=2010 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |location=Oxford |isbn=978-0-19-956995-3 |page= |pages= |laysummary=http://ukcatalogue.oup.com/product/9780199569953.do |laydate=24 November 2010 |ref=harv }} *[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=creativity-roots-human-genius-deeper-than-expected ''The Roots of Human Genius Are Deeper Than Expected''] (March 10, 2013) [[Scientific American]] * {{cite book |title=Origins of Genius: Darwinian Perspectives on Creativity |author=Dean Keith Simonton |year=1999 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0195128796 }} * [[Isaac Asimov]] (2014-10-20) [http://www.technologyreview.com/view/531911/isaac-asimov-mulls-how-do-people-get-new-ideas/ on Cultivating Creativity] * [[John Cleese]] (2014-08-08) [http://www.fastcocreate.com/1680999/4-lessons-in-creativity-from-john-cleese on Fostering Creativity]

[[File:NyungkalCIMS.jpg|300px|thumb|Sample of cultural mapping: [[Kuku Nyungkal]] cultural information system]] '''Cultural mapping''', also known as cultural resource mapping or cultural landscape mapping, is the label organisations and people (including [[UNESCO]]) concerned about safeguarding [[cultural diversity]] give to a wide range of [[Research#Research methods|research techniques and tools]] used to "[[map]]" distinct [[Ethnic group|peoples]]' tangible and intangible [[cultural heritage|cultural assets]] within local [[cultural landscape|landscapes]] around the world.[http://www.unescobkk.org/culture/cultural-diversity/cultural-mapping/ UNESCO Bangkok "Cultural Mapping" webpage] Accessed 21 December 2010
In its [[Universal Declaration on Cultural Diversity]], UNESCO notes the importance of States adopting inclusive ways of encouraging cultural diversity...[http://www.ibcperu.org/doc/isis/11953.pdf Peter Poole (2003) Cultural Mapping and Indigenous People: A Report to UNESCO] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726164459/http://www.ibcperu.org/doc/isis/11953.pdf |date=2011-07-26 }}
Cultural mapping is also used to describe the use of research methods, tools, and techniques to identify, describe, portray, promote, and plan future use of particular regions' or cities' combined cultural assets and resources:
A broadly-based mapping exercise for purposes of investigating or creating an identity profile of the community is enriching, informative and useful ... The process of mapping by itself draws attention to the existence and importance of cultural resources. The results point out problems to be solved or strengths to build upon.[http://www.2010legaciesnow.com/fileadmin/user_upload/ExploreArts/Toolkits/CultureMapping.pdf Arts Now (2007) Cultural Mapping Toolkit. Creativecity.ca]
Cultural mapping is an emerging interdisciplinary field in which a range of perspectives are used as:
a mode of inquiry and a methodological tool in urban planning, cultural sustainability, and community development that makes visible the ways local stories, practices, relationships, memories, and rituals constitute places as meaningful locations."Nancy Duxbury, W.F. Garrett-Petts, David MacLennan Editors Cultural Mapping as Cultural Inquiry Routledge Advances in Research Methods Routledge, May 22, 2015 [https://books.google.com/books?id=51CsCQAAQBAJ] {{ISBN|9781317588009}}
==See also== * [[Cultural landscape]] * [[Participatory GIS]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Culture}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cultural mapping}} [[Category:Cultural geography]] {{cultural-studies-stub}} {{Anthropology-stub}} {{geo-term-stub}}

{{Culture of Qatar}} The '''culture of [[Qatar]]''' is strongly influenced by traditional [[Arab culture|Bedouin culture]], with less acute influence deriving from [[India]], [[East Africa]] and elsewhere in the [[Persian Gulf]]. The peninsula's harsh climatic conditions compelled its inhabitants to turn to the sea for sustenance. Thus, there is a distinct emphasis placed on the sea in local culture.<ref>{{cite book|last=Abu Saud|first=Abeer|title=Qatari Women: Past and Present|publisher=Longman Group United Kingdom|date=1984|isbn=978-0582783720|page=133}}</ref> Literature and folklore themes are often related to sea-based activities.
Oral arts such as poetry and singing were historically more prevalent than [[figurative art]] because of the restrictions placed by [[Aniconism in Islam|Islam on depictions of sentient beings]]; however, certain visual art disciplines such as calligraphy, architecture and textile arts were widely practiced. Figurative arts were gradually assimilated into the country's culture during the [[History of Qatar#Oil drilling|oil era]].<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 134</ref>
Since 2016, [[Salah bin Ghanim Al Ali]] has been the [[Ministry of Culture and Sports (Qatar)|Minister for Culture and Sports]] of Qatar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oxgaps.org/files/interview_al_ali.pdf|title=Interview: H.E. Salah bin Ghanem Al Ali - Minister of Culture and Sports - State of Qatar|publisher=Oxford Gulf & Arabian Peninsula Forum|year=2016|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
==Visual arts== {{Main|Qatari art}} {{See also|Collecting practices of the Al-Thani Family}} [[File:Museum of Islamic arts SOP.jpg|thumb|right|[[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]]]] Because of [[Islam]]'s [[Aniconism in Islam|stance on figurative art]], paintings and [[plastic arts]] played a relatively insignificant role in Qatari culture until the discovery of oil in the mid-20th century.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 140</ref> Other visual arts such as [[Islamic calligraphy|calligraphy]] and [[Islamic architecture|architecture]] were the most historically dominant forms of Islamic visual expression. Calligraphy was most prized in society because of its close connection with Islam.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 141</ref> Calligraphy is often used in the design of official state [[logo]]s, for example, the [[Qatar National Vision 2030]] logo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culturaldiplomacy.org/academy/content/pdf/participant-papers/2013-08-acd/Aysha_Khalid_Mahmood_-_Expressions_of_Arabic_Calligraphy_in_Arabic_Typography_for_a_Cultural_Identity_of_the_Visual_Arabic_Script.pdf|publisher=Cultural Diplomacy|title=Expressions of Arabic Calligraphy in Arabic Typography for a Cultural Identity of the Visual Arabic Script|author=Aysha Khalid Mahmood|page=8|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
[[Art exhibition]]s were held under the auspices of the Ministry of Education until 1972, whereupon the state began providing its full support to the art scene. The Qatari Fine Arts Society was established in 1980 with the objective of promoting the works of Qatari artists.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 142</ref> [[Yousef Ahmad]] is a leading figure of Qatar's art industry and regularly represents the country at international biennials and events. His art work has been displayed internationally.<ref>{{cite book|last=McCoy|first=Lisa|title=Qatar (Major Muslim Nations)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UMwdBQAAQBAJ|publisher=Mason Crest|year=2014}}</ref>
[[File:Mathaf Arab Museum of Modern Art at Education City.jpg|thumb|left|Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art interior in 2011]] For the last twenty years, several members of the [[House of Thani|Al Thani]] family have led Qatar’s interest and involvement into the field of arts and continue to shape the cultural policy of the country.<ref>{{cite web|author=Robert Kluijver|url=http://gulfartguide.com/essay/the-al-thanis-involvement-in-the-arts/|title=The Al Thani’s involvement in the arts|publisher=Gulf Art Guide|accessdate=15 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518093205/http://gulfartguide.com/essay/the-al-thanis-involvement-in-the-arts/|archivedate=18 May 2015|df=}}</ref> Qatar was revealed to be the world's biggest art buyer in 2011 by [[The Art Newspaper]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/jul/13/qatar-world-biggest-art-buyer|title=Qatar becomes world's biggest buyer of contemporary art|publisher=The Guardian|date=13 July 2011|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
[[Qatar Museums]] was established in the early 2000s to build and connect all museums and collections in Qatar. Two major museums lead the institution: the [[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha|Museum of Islamic Art]] opened in 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/focus/2008/11/20081122145957210396.html|title=Qatar unveils Islamic arts museum|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=23 November 2008|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref> and the [[Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art]], opened in [[Education City]] by [[Qatar Foundation]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6swDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA165&lpg=PA165|title=Art and the Global Economy|publisher=University of California Press|author=John Zarobell|page=165|year=2017}}</ref>
When a quartet comprising Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain and Egypt [[2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis|severed all ties]] with and imposed a blockade of Qatar on 5 June 2017, Qatari artist Ahmed Al-Maadheed created an illustration known as "Tamim Almajd", which translates to "Tamim the Glorious". The illustration, a simple black and white sketch of Emir [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]] containing the text "Tamim Almajd" in the style of [[Arabic calligraphy]], has become symbolic of Qatari nationalism. The image is now displayed prominently on buildings, in media and in art in Qatar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/tamim-the-glorious-enthrals-qatar/article19421398.ece|title=‘Tamim the Glorious’ enthrals Qatar|publisher=The Hindu|agency=AFP|date=3 August 2017|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref>
==Folklore== [[File:DhowFestivalQatar.jpg|thumb|left|A large dhow historically used for pearling at a Qatari dhow festival]] Local folk stories were seldom documented, instead being passed down orally from generation to generation. After Qatar began profitting from oil exploration, the tradition of passing down these stories gradually ceased. Government ministries such as the [[Ministry of Culture and Sports (Qatar)|Ministry of Culture and Sports]] and local universities have made efforts to preserve and transcribe local legends in publications.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.csmonitor.com/The-Culture/Arts/2011/0328/Saving-the-stories|title=Saving the stories|publisher=Christian Science Monitor|author=Amanda Erickson|date=28 March 2011|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
Among Qatar's most noted [[folk hero]]es are [[Qatari ibn al-Fuja'a]], a 7th-century [[war poet]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adab.com/modules.php?name=Sh3er&doWhat=ssd&shid=343|title=نبذة حول الشاعر: قطري بن الفجاءة|publisher=Adab|language=Arabic|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> and [[Rahmah ibn Jabir Al Jalhami]], an 18th- and 19th-century pirate and transitory leader of Qatar.<ref>{{cite book|authorlink=Allen James Fromherz|author=Allen J. Fromherz|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dr8rDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA49|title=Qatar: A Modern History, Updated Edition|publisher=Georgetown University Press|page=49|date=1 June 2017}}</ref> Recurring themes in Qatari folk tales are [[djinn]], pearl diving, and the sea.<ref name="Pechcin">{{cite book|url=http://www.academia.edu/34106946/A_Tale_of_The_Lord_of_the_Sea_in_Qatari_Folklore_and_Tradition|title=Fictional Beings in Middle East Cultures|chapter=A Tale of “The Lord of the Sea” in Qatari Folklore and Tradition|publisher=University of Bucharest's Center for Arab Studies|author=Katarzyna Pechcin|year=2017|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
One [[myth]] that purportedly originates from Qatar is that of ''May and Gilan'', the latter of whom is said to be progenitor of the [[sail]]. According to tradition, in old times, a wealthy man named Ghilan resided in [[Al Khor (city)|Al Khor]]. Besides commanding a crew of sailors and fishermen, he owned numerous [[Pearl hunting|pearling]] boats. As time passed, a woman named May who commanded superior number of boats and crewmen emerged as Ghilan's main adversary.<ref name="mayghilan"/>
[[File:Arab pearl divers in the Persian Gulf.jpg|thumb|Pearl diving in the Persian Gulf]] In an incident in which both crews were attempting to harvest the same pearl bed, May taunted Ghilan as her ship raced past his. This incensed Ghilan, who set out to discover a way to best his competitor. While observing a grasshopper, Ghilan took note of how its wings worked, and applied the same principle to his boats, giving rise to the sail. This enabled his boats to travel at higher speeds, allowing him to outpace May's boats to the densest pearl beds. The myth is typically presented in five sequences and is unlike most other known [[Bedouin]] stories. According to locals of Al Khor, the myth originated from the [[Al Muhannadi]] tribe of Al Khor. The story is not well-known elsewhere in Qatar.<ref name="mayghilan">{{cite web|url=https://journals.openedition.org/tc/1161|title=La légende de May et Ghilân, mythe d’origine de la pêche des perles ?|journal=Techniques & Culture|year=2004|author=Anie Montigny|pages=43–44|language=French|accessdate=21 August 2018}}</ref>
The ''Lord of the Sea'' tale is famous in Qatar as well as the rest of the Persian Gulf region. The story revolves around a water djinn in the Persian Gulf named Bū Daryā who terrorizes sailors and pearl divers. It remains a well-known tale among Qatar's older population, particularly those who worked in maritime activities.<ref name="Pechcin"/>
==Literature== {{Main|Qatari literature}} Qatari literature dates back to the 19th century with poets such as Abdul Jalil Al-Tabatabai and Mohammed bin Abdullah bin Uthaymeen. However, due to widespread illiteracy in the region at this time, local written literature dating back to the 19th century is scarce.<ref name="tawfiq">{{cite web|url=http://aljasra.org/archive/cms/?p=2727|title=الشعر في قطر علي امتداد مائة سنة|publisher=Al Jasra Cultural and Social Club|author=Hassan Tawfiq|language=Arabic|date=1 May 2015|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
The modern literature movement in Qatar began in the 1950s, during the same time as the [[Qatari art|modern arts movement]]. This was largely because the increased prosperity from oil extraction activities allowed Qataris to receive formal education, adopt more settled lifestyles and attend higher education institutes abroad in order to hone their creative skills.<ref name="tawfiq"/> Other factors involved in triggering a literary revolution were the improved social standing of women, the advent of a national identity, and the introductions of literary organisations, journalism and mass immigration.<ref name="oxford1">{{cite book|author=Waïl S. Hassan (book editor), Mohammed Mostafa Salem (chapter 22)|title=The Oxford Handbook of Arab Novelistic Traditions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TXAuDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA384|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=383–393|chapter=22|date=1 August 2017}}</ref>
Unlike most other forms of art in Qatari society, females have been involved in the literature movement on a similar magnititude to males.<ref>{{cite book|authors=Rebecca L. Torstrick & Elizabeth Faier|title=Culture and Customs of the Arab Gulf States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jwp6D51NB34C&pg=PA45|publisher=Greenwood|page=49|year=2009|isbn=978-0313336591}}</ref> Yousef Ni'ma introduced the first two collections of short stories in 1970, entitled ''Bint Al-Khaleej (Daughter of the Gulf)'' and ''Liqa fi Beirut (A Meeting in Bayrut)''.<ref name="oxford1"/> In the 1970s, much of the early work of females revolved around ''ritha'' poems which were published in local newspapers.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 158</ref> [[Kaltham Jaber]] became the first Qatari woman to publish a collection of short stories,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/qatar/al-sharq-news/20151014/282716225832524|title=ﻨﻈﻤﻬﺎ إدارة «اﻟﺒﺤﻮث واﻟﺪراﺳﺎت» ﻧﺪوة ﺛﻘﺎﻓﻴﺔ ﺗﻮﺛﻖ ﻟﻠﺴﺮد اﻟﻘﻄﺮي ﻧﻬﺎﻳﺔ أﻛﺘﻮﺑﺮ|publisher=Al Sharq|website=pressreader.com|language=Arabic|date=14 October 2015|accessdate=23 July 2017}}</ref> and the first Qatari woman writer to publish a major work when she released her anthology of short stories, dating from 1973 to the year of its publishing, 1978.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 161</ref> Entitled "''Ania wa Ghabat as-Samt wa at-Taraddud''", the main focus of these stories is the desire for Qatari women to have a role in restructuring social norms and cultural conceptions.<ref>{{cite book|last=Subayyil|first=ʻAbd al-ʻAzīz|title=The Short Story in the Arabian Peninsula: Realistic Trends|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qjceAQAAMAAJ|publisher=Indiana University|year=1991|page=28}}</ref>
[[File:AbdulazizAlMahmoud.jpg|thumb|left|[[Abdulaziz Al-Mahmoud]], Qatari novelist]] In the late 20th and the 21st centuries, novels became popular among Qatari writers. [[Shu'a' Khalifa]] and her sister [[Dalal Khalifa]] were the first two Qatari novelists to publish their works. They accomplished this feat with the publishing of three separate novels in 1993: ''al-Ubur ila al-haqiqa (Passage to Truth)'', written by Shu'a' in 1987, Ahlam al-bahr al-qadima (The Old Dreams of the Sea), written by Shu'a' in 1990 and ''Usturat al-Insan wa-l-buhayra (The Myth of the Man and the Lake'', written by Dalal. Their novels center around social limitations faced by women, and scrutinize long-held social values. Another important theme in their novels is the rapid societal transition experienced by Qatar since the discovery of oil.<ref name="oxford1"/>
[[Abdulaziz Al-Mahmoud]] published his maritime novel ''Al Qursan'' in August 2011, and it went on to become one of the best-selling books to be released by a Qatari author.<ref name>{{cite web|url=http://www.qf.org.qa/content/the-foundation/issue-53/sharing-the-secrets-of-literary-success|title=Sharing The Secrets Of Literary Success|publisher=Qatar Foundation|date=14 May 2013|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref> By June 2015, twelve Qatari women and eight Qatari men had published a collective total of thirty-nine novels.<ref name="oxford1"/> Novels have proven to be one of the fastest growing categories of literature, with nearly a quarter of all existing Qatari-authored novels being published as recently as 2014. Six new female Qatari writers published novels in 2014. Similar to their predecessors, the main themes in their books are women's role in society and the social transition of Qatar.<ref name="oxford1"/>
===Poetry=== [[File:Traditional dhow festival in Qatar.jpg|thumb|Traditional dhow festival held at [[Katara Cultural Village]]]] Poetry has been an integral part of the culture since pre-Islamic times.<ref name="abusaud1">Abu Saud (1984), p. 152</ref> [[Qatari ibn al-Fuja'a]], a [[folk hero]] dating to the seventh-century, was renowned for writing poetry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adab.com/modules.php?name=Sh3er&doWhat=ssd&shid=343|title=نبذة حول الشاعر: قطري بن الفجاءة|publisher=Adab|language=Arabic|accessdate=25 August 2018}}</ref> It was seen as a verbal art which fulfilled essential social functions. Having a renowned poet among its ranks was a source of pride for tribes; it is the primary way in which age-old traditions are passed down generations. Poems composed by females primarily focused on the theme of ''ritha'', to lament. This type of poetry served as an [[elegy]].<ref name="abusaud1"/>
[[Nabati]] was the primary form of oral poetry. In the nineteenth-century, sheikh [[Jassim bin Mohammed Al Thani|Jassim Al Thani]] composed influential Nabati poems on the political conditions in Qatar.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 154</ref> Nabati poems are broadcast on radio and televised in the country.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 156</ref>
==Music== {{Main|Music of Qatar}} [[File:TraditionalQatariDancers.jpg|thumb|240px|Traditional Qatari male dancers]]
The [[folk music]] of Qatar has a close association with the sea. Songs related to [[pearl hunting]] are the most popular genre of male folk music. Each song, varying in rhythm, narrates a different activity of the pearling trip, including spreading the sails, diving, and rowing the ships. Collective singing was an integral part of each pearling trip, and each ship had a designated singer, known locally as ''al naham''.<ref name="abusaud146">Abu Saud (1984), p. 146</ref>
[[Ardah]], a folkloric dance, is still practiced in Qatar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qatarembassy.info/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=61:arts-and-culture&catid=12:tourism-culture-and-leisure&Itemid=4|title=Arts and Culture|publisher=Embassy of Qatar in London|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> The dance is performed with two rows of men opposite of one another, each of whom may or may not be wielding a sword, and is accompanied by drums and spoken poetry.<ref>{{cite book|last=Urkevich|first=Lisa|title=Music and Traditions of the Arabian Peninsula: Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, and Qatar|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gy-cBQAAQBAJ|format=Google Play|pages=142–143/689|chapter=5|publisher=Routledge|date=19 December 2014|isbn=978-0415888721}}</ref>
Historically, women primarily sang work songs associated with daily activities such as wheat grinding and cooking. The songs were performed collectively in small groups some pertained to general themes, whereas others were related to specific work processes.<ref name="abusaud2"/> Women would also sing when returning pearl ships were sighted.<ref name="abusaud146"/> After a sighting was made, they would gather around the seashore where they would clap and sing about the hardships of pearl diving.<ref name="abusaud2">Abu Saud (1984), p. 147</ref>
==Sport== [[File:AlGharafa AlRayyan Emir Cup.jpg|thumb|left|National anthem being performed prior to an [[Emir of Qatar Cup|Emir Cup final]].]] {{Main|Sport in Qatar}} [[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in regard to player base and spectatorship. Additionally, [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]], [[basketball]], [[team handball|handball]], [[volleyball]], [[camel racing]], [[horse racing]], [[cricket]] and [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]] are widely practiced.<ref name="qsa1">{{cite web|url=http://www.qsa.gov.qa/eng/publication/annabs/2013/Sport%20chapter.xlsx|title=Sports chapter (2013)|publisher=Qatar Statistics Authority|accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref> There are currently 11 multi-sports clubs in the country, and 7 single-sports clubs.<ref name="qsa1"/>
Prior to the introduction of football, traditional games played were ''al dahroi'', ''al sabbah'', and ''taq taq taqiyyah'' for boys, and ''al kunatb'', ''al laqfah'' and ''nat al habl'' for girls.<ref name="catnaps">{{cite web|url=http://catnaps.org/islamic/society2.html|title=Society 2 of 6|publisher=Catnaps|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> Variations of a family of board games known as [[mancala]] were played in previous decades. Two of the most popular board games were ''a’ailah'' and ''al haluwsah''.<ref name="catnaps"/> Other traditional sports practiced in the country include [[falconry]], camel racing and hunting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qatartourism.gov.qa/en/traditional-sports.html|title=Traditional sports|publisher=Qatar Tourism Authority|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Board game damah at Souq Waqif.jpg|thumb|Two men playing the traditional board game of ''damah'' in [[Souq Waqif]]]] Historically camel racing was a tradition among the [[Bedouin]] tribes of Qatar and would be performed on special occasions such as weddings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0022/002240/224033e.pdf |title=The Camel From Tradition to Modern Times |first1=Marc |last1=Breulmann |first2=Benno |last2=Böer |first3=Ulrich |last3=Wernery |first4=Renate |last4=Wernery |first5=Hassan |last5=El Shaer |first6=Ghaleb |last6=Alhadrami |first7=David |last7=Gallacher |first8=John |last8=Peacock |first9=Shaukat Ali |last9=Chaudhary |first10=Gary |last10=Brown |first11=John |last11=Norton |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=23 August 2018|lastauthoramp=yes}}{{rp|25}}</ref> It was not until 1972, one year after Qatar's independence, that camel racing was practiced on a professional level. Typically, camel racing season takes place from September to March. Approximately 22,000 racing camels are used in competitions which are mainly held at the country's primary camel racing venue, the Al-Shahaniya Camel Racetrack. The average distance of such races is usually 4 to 8 km depending on the conditions of the camels being raced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenational.ae/world/qatar-s-prized-racing-camels-bred-for-success-1.634580|title=Qatar's prized racing camels bred for success|publisher=Agence France-Presse|website=thenational.ae|author=David Harding|date=1 May 2017|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref>
Falconry is widely practiced by Qataris. The only falconry association is Al Gannas, which was founded in 2008 in [[Katara (cultural village)|Katara]] and which hosts the Annual Falconry Festival. Hunting season extends from October to April. Prices of falcons can be extremely high, being as expensive as QR 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marhaba.qa/falconry-a-national-sport/|title=Falconry: A National Sport|publisher=Marhaba|date=20 September 2017|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> [[Saluki]] dogs are also used for hunting in the desert primarily because of their great speeds. Their main prey in the desert are [[gazelle]]s and rabbits.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/inpictures/2012/01/201212911847243824.html|title=In Pictures: Qatar's hunting games|publisher=Al Jazeera|author=Matthew Cassel|date=29 January 2012|accessdate=26 August 2018}}</ref>
==Food and drink== [[File:Qatari Sweets Souq Waqif Doha.jpg|thumb|left|Qatari sweets in [[Souq Waqif]]]] {{Main|Qatari cuisine}} As Qatar follows Shariah Law, alcohol and pork products cannot be brought into the country. Qatari cuisine reflects traditional [[Arab cuisine|Arab]] and [[Levantine cuisine]].<ref name="dailymeal">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailymeal.com/3-m-s-qatari-cuisine|title=The 3 M’s of Qatari Cuisine|publisher=The Daily Meal|date=3 October 2012|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> It is also heavily influenced by [[Iranian cuisine|Iranian]] and [[Indian cuisine]]. [[Seafood]] and [[Date (fruit)|dates]] are staple food items.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hilalplaza.com/islamic-culture/Qatar/Qatar_Muslim_culture.html|title=Culture of Qatar|publisher=Hilal Plaza|accessdate=6 May 2015}}</ref> [[Kabsa|Machbūs]], a meal consisting of [[rice]], [[meat]], and [[vegetable]]s, is the national dish.<ref name="dailymeal"/>
[[Alcohol]] is not illegal in Qatar, but its sale and consumption is heavily regulated. Muslims are prohibited from purchasing and consuming alcohol. A liquor license is required to buy alcohol.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lifeinqatar.com/en/article/living/culture-and-etiquette-in-qatar.html|title=Culture and Etiquette in Qatar|publisher=Life in Qatar|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
==Dress== [[File:Mannequins in traditional Qatari women's attire.jpg|thumb|Mannequins in traditional Qatari women's attire at [[Sheikh Faisal Bin Qassim Al Thani Museum]]]] Qatari men wear [[thawb]]s (a long white shirt) over loose pants. They also wear a loose headdress, a [[Keffiyeh|ghutra]], which comes in white or red and white.<ref name="weill">{{cite web|url=https://qatar-weill.cornell.edu/aboutUs/qa/qCulture.html|title=Qatar culture|publisher=Weill Cornell Medical College in Qatar|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> Around the ghutra is a black rope called an agal which holds it in place.<ref name=Hilal/>
Qatari women generally wear customary dresses that include “long black robes” and black head cover "hijab", locally called ''bo'shiya''.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 39</ref><ref name=ABC>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/story?id=79539&page=1#.UbToAflOQto|title=For Qatari Women, Change Slow in Coming|publisher=ABC News|author=Courtney King|date=11 April 2003|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref> However, the more traditional Sunni Muslim clothing for women are the black colored body covering known as the [[abayah]] together with the black scarf used for covering their heads known as the [[Shaylah (clothing)|shayla]].<ref name=Hilal>{{cite web|url=http://www.hilalplaza.com/islamic-culture/Qatar/Qatar_Muslim_culture.html|title=The Culture of Qatar|publisher=HilalPlaza|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref> A [[burqa]] is sometimes worn to conceal their face.<ref name="weill">{{cite web|url=https://qatar-weill.cornell.edu/aboutUs/qa/qCulture.html|title=Qatar culture|publisher=Weill Cornell Medical College in Qatar|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
It is believed that Qatari women began using face masks in the 19th century amid substantial immigration. As they had no practical ways of concealing their faces from foreigners, they began wearing the same type of face mask as their Persian counterparts.<ref>Abu Saud (1984), p. 52</ref>
==Holidays== {{See also|Public holidays in Qatar}} Qatar's weekends are Friday and Saturday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officeholidays.com/countries/qatar/index.php|title=Public Holidays in Qatar in 2015|publisher=Office Holidays|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> [[Qatar National Day]] was changed from 3 September to 18 December in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeanddate.com/holidays/qatar/national-day|title=National Day Observances|publisher=Timeanddate.com|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> Notable holidays in the country are listed below:
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Date !! English name !! Local ([[Arabic Language|Arabic]]) name !! Description |- | Second Tuesday in February || [[National Sports Day]] || اليوم الوطني للرياضة || A [[public holiday]]. |- | Early March || March bank holiday || عطلة البنك || A [[bank holiday]]. |- | 18 December || [[Qatar National Day]] || اليوم الوطني لقطر || National Day of Qatar. |- | 1st, 2nd, 3rd ''[[Shawwal]]'' || [[Eid ul-Fitr]] || عيد الفطر || Commemorates end of [[Ramadan]]. |- | 10th, 11th, 12th ''[[Dhu al-Hijjah|Zulhijjah]]'' || [[Eid ul-Adha]] || عيد الأضحى || Commemorates [[Abraham|Ibrahim]]'s willingness to sacrifice his son. Also known as the ''Big Feast'' (celebrated from the 10th to 13th). |}
==Media== {{Main|Media of Qatar}} There are currently seven newspapers in circulation in Qatar, with four being published in Arabic and three being published in English.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Report: Qatar 2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BT1gIeuQq6wC|publisher=Oxford Business Group|year=2010|page=237}}</ref> Additionally, there are nine magazines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irex.org/system/files/MENAMSI09_Qatar.pdf|title=IREX Report 2009|publisher=irex.org|accessdate=20 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118181357/http://www.irex.org/system/files/MENAMSI09_Qatar.pdf|archivedate=18 January 2012|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Al jazeera arabic.jpg|thumb|[[Al Jazeera]] Arabic Building]] All radio programmes from Qatar are state-owned and are amalgamated as the Qatar Broadcasting Service.<ref>{{cite book|title=Qatar Country Study Guide Volume 1 Strategic Information and Developments|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y0SbBQAAQBAJ|publisher=Int'l Business Publications, USA|year=2012|page=196|isbn=978-0739762141}}</ref> Radio broadcasting in the country began in June 1968 and English transmissions started in December 1971<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tunein.com/radio/QBS-FM-Radio-s209375/|title=QBS FM Radio - Doha|publisher=tunein.com|accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref> in order to accommodate the increasing non-Arabic speaking expat community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qmediame.com/English/Media_Center/Radio/Pages/default.aspx|title=Radio|publisher=qmediame.com|accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kadhim|first=Abbas|title=Governance in the Middle East and North Africa: A Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G-etiAFUzJ0C|publisher=Routledge|year=2013|page=273|isbn=978-1857435849}}</ref> The QBS currently features radio stations in English, Arabic, French and Urdu.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qatarembassy.net/page/information-and-media#11|title=Information and Media|publisher=qatarembassy.net|accessdate=19 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006095553/http://www.qatarembassy.net/page/information-and-media#11|archivedate=6 October 2014|df=}}</ref>
[[Al Jazeera]], currently Qatar's largest television network, was founded in 1996 and has since become the foundation of the media sector.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Report: Qatar 2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8uk4ZcbbWmgC|publisher=Oxford Business Group|page=200|year=2009|isbn=978-1902339252}}</ref> Initially launched as an Arabic news and [[current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] satellite TV channel, Al Jazeera has since expanded into a network with several outlets, including the internet and [[specialty channel|specialty]] [[television channel|TV channels]] in multiple languages. The '[[Al Jazeera effect]]' refers to the global impact of the [[Al Jazeera Media Network]], particularly on the politics of the [[Arab world]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/the-al-jazeera-effect-arab-satellite-television-and-public-opinion |title=The ‘al-Jazeera Effect’: - The Washington Institute for Near East Policy |publisher=Washingtoninstitute.org |date=2000-12-08 |accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref>
== Television == The multinational media conglomerate [[Al Jazeera Media Network]] is based in Doha with its wide variety of channels of which [[Al Jazeera Arabic]], [[Al Jazeera English]], [[Al Jazeera Documentary Channel]], [[Al Jazeera Mubasher]], [[beIN Sports Arabia]] and other operations are based in the TV Roundabout in the city.
;Terrestrial television Terrestrial television stations now available on Nilesat include: {| class="wikitable" |- !Channel || Signal || Format || Station name || Network || Status |- | style="text-align:center;"| 21 | rowspan=18| UHF | rowspan=18| DVB-T2 | Q Channel Arabia | Lippo Middle East Group | rowspan=8| Local / national |- | style="text-align:center;"| 31 | Al Watania TV | Lippo Middle East Group |- | style="text-align:center;"| 37 | MBC 1<br>MBC 4<br>MBC Action SportOne TV<br>MegaSight TV | VIVA |- | style="text-align:center;"| 39 | Fox ME TV<br>Fox News Arabia<br>Sky News Arabia<br>BBC Arabia<br>CNBC<br>CNN<br>CNTV Arabia (Prabowo Saudia TV) | EMTEK |- | style="text-align:center;"| 41 | LBC Sat<br>CoopTV<br>Infinity TV (Prabowo Saudia TV) | EMTEK |- | style="text-align:center;"| 43 | ITV 1<br>ITV 2<br>Brinklow<br>Meridian | ITV Arabia Group |- | style="text-align:center;"| 45 | Al Jazeera | Al Jazeera Media Network |- | style="text-align:center;"| 47 | OSN First More<br>OSN News<br>Al Yawm<br>Series Channel<br>Pesona HD<br>Inspirasi HD<br>Hidayah HD<br>Emas HD<br>Bintang<br>Tara<br>Pelangi<br>Kiara | OSN MEDIA |- | style="text-align:center;"| 49 | Radar TV<br>MNC Sports 1<br>MNC Sports 2<br>Sport 24<br>Russia Today<br>France 24<br>NHK World Premium | JPMC | rowspan=6| Local |- | style="text-align:center;"| 51 | I-TV<br>I-Music<br>I-Movies<br>Swara Channel<br>GMA Pinoy TV<br>GMA Life TV<br>GMA News TV International | City TV<br>GMA Network |- | style="text-align:center;"| 53 | Qatar TV 1<br>Qatar TV 2<br>Qatar Airways Interactive Info | Q MEDIA |- | style="text-align:center;"| 55 | Colors<br>Sony TV<br>Garuda TV | VIACOM TV18 |- | style="text-align:center;"| 57 | Zee TV<br>Zee Alwan<br>STAR Plus<br>O Channel<br>RTVM KSA 1<br>RTVM KSA 2 | Zee Network |- | style="text-align:center;"| 59 | Ajman TV<br>Infinity TV<br>Noor Dubai TV<br>Al Rayyan TV<br>MDC TV (SINDOtv)<br>DMC TV<br>Elshinta TV<br>Jawa Pos TV | Etisalat<br>JPMC |}
;Pay television * Teledunet * Mozaic TV * MyHD * Mivo TV * Sky (Qatar, UAE, KSA, Kuwait, Oman and Iran only, Pakistan, Palestine, Syria and Iraq opening soon 29 May 2017)
== Radio == Doha has a variety of radio stations, some of which include:
{{col-start}} {{col-3}} ;FM radio * 90.8 – QBS Arabic * 91.7 – QF Radio * 92.0 – MBC FM * 92.6 – Radio Sawa Gulf * 93.7 – QF Radio * 94.0 – Oryx FM French * 97.5 – QBS English * 99.6 – Radio Monte Carlo * 100.3 – Panorama FM * 100.8 – Sout al Khaleej * 101.0 -- Sindo Trijaya FM * 102.0 – Fox News Talk * 102.2 -- Sonora FM * 103.4 – Quran Kareem Radio * 104.6 -- Delta FM * 107.4 – BBC World Service {{col-3}} ;DAB radio * 10B Arabic Multiplex ** C221 – QBS Arabic ** C222 – QF Radio More ** C223 – MBC FM ** C224 – Radio Sawa Gulf ** C225 – QF Radio ** C226 – Oryx FM French ** C227 – QBS English ** C228 – Radio Monte Carlo ** C229 – BBC Arabic Service ** C230 – Panorama FM ** C231 – Sout al Khaleej ** C232 – Fox News Talk ** C233 – Quran Kareem Radio ** C234 – BBC World Service {{col-3}} ;DAB radio * 10C Indonesian Multiplex ** C235 – Sonora FM ** C236 – Delta FM ** C237 – Sindo Trijaya FM {{col-end}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} [[File:Zoo Park Dairy.jpg|thumb|300px|A dairy in [[Newtown, New Zealand]]]]
A '''dairy''' is a small owner-operated [[convenience store]] in [[New Zealand]], licensed to sell [[groceries]], milk, eggs, dairy products, perishables, newspapers and other staples during and after normal trading hours.<ref>{{cite book |title=New Zealand |last=Rawlings-Way |first=Charles |page=63 |isbn=1742203647 |location=[[London]] |publisher= [[Lonely Planet]] |year=2010 }}</ref>
==Origins and usage== The term ''dairy'' came into common usage in [[New Zealand English]] to describe small shops by the late 1930s. Perishables such as milk and eggs were formerly delivered to city households from a [[dairy farm]]; by the late 1930s, small shops stocked such produce, and the term shifted to describe these shops. In addition to this meaning, New Zealand English retains the common meanings of ''dairy'', referring to milk, milk-derived products and associated industries.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Godzone Dictionary: Of Favourite New Zealand Words and Phrases |last=Cryer |first=Max |authorlink=Max Cryer |page=51 |isbn=0908988745 |publisher= Exisle Publishing |location=[[Auckland]] |year=2010 }}</ref><ref name="te ara" />
The distinction between dairies, [[superette]]s and [[grocery store]]s has grown increasingly blurred in New Zealand English, a fact acknowledged by the Liquor Licensing Authority in 1991, and by the [[New Zealand Law Commission|Law Commission]]. Contributing factors to this blurring of meanings include the [[Sunday shopping#New Zealand|deregulation of trading shop hours on Sundays]], ambiguity over alcohol sales laws (see [[#Sales of alcohol and legal highs|Sales of alcohol]] below), and the abolition of restrictions on types of goods permitted to be sold by dairies.<ref name="NZLC">{{cite book |title= Alcohol In Our Lives: Curbing the Harm |date=April 2010 |isbn=978-1-877316-91-3 |publisher=[[New Zealand Law Commission]] |chapter=8 New criteria for selling takeaway alcohol |page=155 |url=http://www.lawcom.govt.nz/sites/default/files/publications/2010/04/Publication_154_464_Part_18_Chapter%208%20-%20New%20criteria%20for%20selling%20takeaway%20alcohol.pdf |accessdate=8 January 2012 }}</ref> The Law Commission summed up the ambiguity as follows:
{{quote|text=Traditionally, a dairy was a small shop in a suburban area that sold goods such as butter, milk, bread and confectionery. It was able to trade outside normal trading hours. Today, the term "dairy" has different meanings for different people, and there seem to be fewer dairies in the traditional sense still in operation, although many shops still have "dairy" in their trading name. |sign=Law Commission |source=Alcohol In Our Lives: Curbing the Harm<ref name="NZLC"/>}}
==Business and culture==
Dairies rely on long hours rather than high mark-ups to make money, and are not overly profitable. As small operators, they cannot get bulk discounts that [[supermarket]]s get. As dairies must remain open long hours to stay profitable, they are almost always family-run businesses that utilise family members to run the shop.<ref name="te ara">{{cite web |title=Food shops – Dairies |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/food-shops/page-5 |last=Walrond |first=Carl |work=[[Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]] |publisher=[[Ministry for Culture and Heritage]] |date=13 July 2012 |accessdate=8 January 2014 }}</ref> New Zealand introduced the 40-hour working week in 1945, ending Saturday trading hours for most grocers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Food shops – Shopping hours |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/food-shops/page-7 |last=Walrond |first=Carl |work=[[Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]] |publisher=[[Ministry for Culture and Heritage]] |date=13 July 2012 |accessdate=8 January 2014 }}</ref> Dairies were allowed to stay open outside normal working hours and on Saturdays.<ref name="te ara" />
During the 1990s and 2000s, dairies became less profitable as other stores made inroads into their niche as nearby stores open outside regular trading hours. As supermarkets opened for longer hours with the introduction of deregulated shopping hours in 1990, and petrol stations extended the range of goods they sold, dairies began to lose their competitive advantage.<ref name="te ara" />
===Immigrant ownership===
A 1994 study found that 227 of the 269 dairies in central [[Auckland]] were owned by [[Indian New Zealander|Indian]]s.<ref name="te ara" /> Dairies are often self-owned by [[immigrant]]s, who may face difficulties entering the workforce. Some dairy owners intended to give their children white collar or professional occupations, while other dairies had inter-generational ownership, with children taking over the store when they reach adulthood.<ref name="te ara" />
The role of dairies in New Zealand's immigrant Indian culture was explored in [[Jacob Rajan]]'s 1997 play ''Krishnan's Dairy'', which toured internationally to positive reviews.<ref>{{cite news |title=Guru returns |last=Chia |first=Adeline |work=[[The Straits Times]] |date=9 February 2012 }}</ref>
===Sales of alcohol and legal highs===
The Sale of Liquor Act (1989) prohibited the sale of liquor in "any shop of a kind commonly known as a dairy",<ref>{{cite act | title = Sale of Liquor Act 1989 | number = 63 | language = English | date = 17 August 1989 | article = 36(3a) | url = http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1989/0063/latest/DLM165640.html | accessdate = 8 January 2014 }}</ref> without explicitly defining what a dairy was. In the wake of the act, dairies began altering their stock in order to qualify for a liquor license. This resulted in "a proliferation of small stores distinguishable from dairies only because they are licensed to sell alcohol."<ref>{{cite news |title=Liquor reforms highlight issues of moral bills |last=Chen |first=Mai |authorlink=Mai Chen |date=30 August 2012 |accessdate = 8 January 2014 |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/opinion/news/article.cfm?c_id=466&objectid=10830333 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]}}</ref> The legislation contributed to the blurring distinction between dairies and grocery stores in New Zealand English.<ref name="NZLC" />
The Sale and Supply of Alcohol Act 2012 sought to close this unintended loophole, clarifying the types of stores eligible to sell alcohol and ensuring dairies and convenience stores cannot sell alcohol.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.govt.nz/policy/sale-and-supply-of-alcohol/whats-changing-and-when/alcohol-law-changes-for-the-industry-december-2013 |title=Alcohol law changes for the industry – December 2013 |publisher=[[New Zealand Ministry of Justice]] |accessdate = 8 January 2014 }}</ref> The law attracted criticism from dairy owners.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Dairies-criticise-alcohol-ban/tabid/421/articleID/252609/Default.aspx |title=Dairies criticise alcohol ban |date= 2 May 2012 |work=[[3 News]] |accessdate = 8 January 2014 }}</ref>
The Psychoactive Substances Act (2013) prohibits dairies from selling legal highs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/wanganui-chronicle/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503426&objectid=11170559 |author=Court Reporter |date=11 December 2013 |title=First conviction for selling 'legal highs' |publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate = 8 January 2014 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Milk bar]] {{portalbar|New Zealand|Food|Drink}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.newzealand.com/au/article/the-kiwi-dairy/ The Kiwi Dairy] at [[Tourism New Zealand]] website

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Use British English Oxford spelling|date=June 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{About||the 2011 Norwegian film|Dark Souls (film)|the 2007 video game|Bleach: Dark Souls}} {{Infobox video game | title = Dark Souls | image = Dark Souls Cover Art.jpg | caption = Cover art used in Western regions | developer = [[FromSoftware]] | publisher = [[Namco Bandai Games]]{{vgrelease|JP|FromSoftware}} | director = [[Hidetaka Miyazaki]] | producer = {{ubl|Hidetaka Miyazaki|Daisuke Uchiyama|Kei Hirono}} | designer = | programmer = Jun Ito | artist = Makoto Sato | writer = | composer = [[Motoi Sakuraba]] | series = ''[[Souls (series)|Souls]]'' | engine = | platforms = [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], [[Nintendo Switch]] |released={{collapsible list|title=September 22, 2011|titlestyle=font-weight:normal;font-size:inherit;background:transparent;text-align:left|'''PlayStation 3''', '''Xbox 360'''{{vgrelease|JP|September 22, 2011{{efn|For the PlayStation 3 only}}|NA|October 4, 2011|AU|October 6, 2011|EU|October 7, 2011}}'''Windows'''{{vgrelease|AU|August 23, 2012|NA|August 24, 2012|EU|August 24, 2012|JP|October 25, 2012}}'''PlayStation 4''', '''Xbox One'''{{vgrelease|JP|May 24, 2018|WW|May 25, 2018}}'''Nintendo Switch''' {{vgrelease|WW|October 19, 2018}}}} | genre = [[Action role-playing]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] }}
'''''Dark Souls'''''{{efn|{{Nihongo|ダークソウル|Dāku Sōru|lead=yes}}}} is an [[action role-playing game]] developed by [[FromSoftware]] and published by [[Namco Bandai Games]]. A [[spiritual successor]] to FromSoftware's ''[[Demon's Souls]]'', the game is the second installment in the ''[[Souls (series)|Souls]]'' series. It was released for the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] in Japan by FromSoftware in September 2011 and worldwide by Namco Bandai Games in the following month. ''Dark Souls'' takes place in the fictional kingdom of Lordran, where players assume the role of a cursed undead character who begins a [[pilgrimage]] to discover the fate of their kind.
''Dark Souls'' received critical acclaim upon its release and is considered to be one of the [[best video games ever released]], with critics praising the depth of its combat, intricate level design, and world lore. However, the game's difficulty received mixed reviews. While some praised the challenge it provides, others criticized it for being unnecessarily unforgiving. The Windows version of the game was less well received, with criticism directed at numerous technical issues.
In August 2012, a version of ''Dark Souls'' for [[Microsoft Windows]], ''[[#PC version|Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition]]'', was released. It featured additional content not seen in the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions. In October 2012, the additional content was released as [[downloadable content]] for consoles under the subtitle ''[[Dark Souls: Artorias of the Abyss|Artorias of the Abyss]]''. By April 2013, the game had sold over two million copies worldwide. A sequel to the game, ''[[Dark Souls II]]'', was released in 2014. A remastered version of the game, ''[[#Dark Souls: Remastered|Dark Souls: Remastered]]'', was released for [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], Windows, and [[Nintendo Switch]] in 2018.
== Gameplay == [[File:Darksoulsbattle.jpg|thumb|left|The [[player character]] (right) battling Knight Artorias, one of the bosses added to the game through [[downloadable content]]]] ''Dark Souls'' is a third-person [[action role-playing game]]. The core mechanic of the game is exploration. Players are encouraged by the game to proceed with caution, learn from past mistakes, or find alternative areas to explore. ''Dark Souls'' takes place in a large and continuous [[open world]] environment, connected through a central hub area (Firelink Shrine). Players are able to travel to and from areas and explore various paths at will, although certain prerequisites have to be met in order to unlock certain areas.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/10/03/dark-souls-review-brick-walls-and-pancakes/ |title=Dark Souls review: Brick walls and pancakes |work=Engadget |date=October 3, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2016 |first=Richard |last=Mitchell}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.ign.com/articles/2011/09/30/dark-souls-review |title=Dark Souls Review |work=IGN |date=September 30, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/dark_souls/b/ps3/archive/2011/10/03/dark-souls-review-dead-and-loving-it.aspx |title=Dark Souls Review: Dead And Loving It |work=GameInformer.com |date=October 3, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2016 |first=Phil |last=Kollar}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.gamerevolution.com/review/dark-souls |title=Dark Souls Review |work=Game Revolution |date=October 3, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2016 |first=Daniel |last=Bischoff}}</ref>
The central element to ''Dark Souls'' are [[Bonfire (Dark Souls)|Bonfires]]. Bonfires are scattered throughout the world and serve as checkpoints for each level. When rested at, the player is healed to full, healing charges are restored, but all of the enemies (except for bosses, mini-bosses, and specific characters) respawn. While resting, players can level up and perform other key functions.
Another aspect of ''Dark Souls'' is the "humanity" system. There are two "forms" the player character can be in during the game, human form and hollow form. Whenever the player dies in human form, they are returned to hollow form and can only have their humanity restored by consuming an item (also called a "humanity"). In order to gain the assistance of other players, the player must be in human form. While in human form, the player is subjected to invasions by other players and [[non-player character]]s (NPC) who seek to kill the player and restore their own humanity. Humanity can be acquired in many ways, and if no humanity is available, players are still able to progress in hollow form. Death in either form results in the loss of all carried souls and humanity, but players revive as hollows at their most recent bonfire with one chance at returning to where they died to recover all lost souls and humanity. If the player dies before reaching their "bloodstain", the souls and humanity they previously accrued are permanently lost.
Communication between players is deliberately restricted. Outside of character gestures, the only other communication players have with one another comes by way of orange [[soapstone]]s, which allow players to write limited messages that can be read by others in the same area. In addition, players can enter [[co-cooperative]] or [[player versus player]] combat with each other.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gamesradar.com/how-dark-souls-pvp-keeping-game-alive/|title=The rituals, strategies, honour and etiquette that keep Dark Souls PvP alive|last=Ahmed|first=Sayem|date=August 26, 2015|work=Future Publishing Limited Quay House|access-date=August 13, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.bandainamcoent.eu/dark-souls/news/master-online-play-vaativiyda|title=Master Online play|last=Entertainment|first=Bandai|date=June 25, 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Throughout the game, there are multiple NPCs that the player may encounter on their journey. These characters add to the plot of the game but are not mandatory to engage with. If the player does choose to engage with them, the characters are able to assist the player by being able to be summoned for certain boss fights.
== Plot == Dark Souls has a minimalist plot. Historical events in this world and their significance are often implicit and left to player interpretation rather than fully shown or explained. Most of the story is given to the player through dialogue from characters within the game, flavor text from items, and world design. The opening cutscene establishes the premise of the game. The world was once ruled by dragons. In this time period, a man known as Gwyn happens upon an object known as the "First Flame" and finds the "Lord Souls". He and his allies use their power to defeat the dragons, which starts the Age of Fire. Over time, the flames begin to fade with the rise of humans, and Gwyn sacrifices himself to prolong the Age of Fire. With the flame artificially rekindled, the undead curse begins to plague humanity, causing certain humans to continually resurrect upon death.
The game's protagonist is known as the chosen undead. After going through Sens Fortress, the chosen undead defeats the Iron Golem, and soon enters taken into Anor Londo. The Chosen Undead defeats Dragonslayer Ornstein and Executioner Smough and then enters a throne room of Gwynevere, who gives the chosen undead an object known as the "Lordvessel". Optionally, the player may encounter Darkstalker Kaathe who encourages the player not to link the fire but to let it die out and usher in the Age of Dark instead. Once the player acquires the Lord Souls, they travel to the Kiln of the First Flame to battle Gwyn. Once Gwyn has been defeated, the player is given the choice of linking the flame to preserve the Age of Fire, or letting it die out to instigate the Age of Dark.
=== ''Artorias of the Abyss'' === {{Main|Dark Souls: Artorias of the Abyss}} At some point in the past, a being known as Manus awoke and began to spread the Abyss. Knight Artorias was sent to stop the spread of the Abyss, but he failed and became corrupted. Meanwhile, Manus searches desperately for his long-lost pendant across space and time. Once the player obtains the pendant, Manus pulls them into the past. There, the player destroys the corrupted Artorias and defeats Manus, halting the spread of the Abyss.
== Development and release == [[File:876MilanoDuomo.JPG|thumb|275px|right|Game director and producer [[Hidetaka Miyazaki]] modeled various places in the game after real-world locations, such as basing the main building in Anor Londo after the [[Milan Cathedral]] in Italy]] {{Expand section|date=June 2018}}
''Dark Souls'' was developed by [[FromSoftware]], with series creator [[Hidetaka Miyazaki]] directing and producing. Following the game's release for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360, many gamers expressed their hope for a PC version. International publisher [[Namco Bandai Games]] administrator Tony Shoupinou responded on their page that a PC version was possible.<ref>{{cite web |last=Conditt |first=Jessica |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2012/01/08/dark-souls-admin-suggests-pc-could-happen-with-a-petition/ |title=Dark Souls admin suggests PC could happen with a petition |publisher=Joystiq |date=January 8, 2012 |accessdate=December 8, 2012}}</ref> In early 2012, fans started a petition to bring ''Dark Souls'' to PC, with over 93,000 people signing it.<ref name="pc_petition">{{cite web |title=Petition: Dark Souls for PC |url=http://petitionbureau.org/DarkSoulsForPC/ |date=January 6, 2012}}</ref> A PC version of the game was confirmed in April 2012 via German magazine ''PC Action''.<ref>{{cite web |last=Donaldson |first=Alex |url=http://www.rpgsite.net/news/1512-dark-souls-pc-confirmed-in-pc-action-magazine |title=Dark Souls PC confirmed in PC Action magazine |website=rpgsite.net |date=April 7, 2012 |accessdate=October 26, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026202607/http://www.rpgsite.net/news/1512-dark-souls-pc-confirmed-in-pc-action-magazine |archive-date=October 26, 2016}}</ref> It had been reported during the development process that FromSoftware had been having difficulty with the port due to inexperience with PC as a platform and were focusing on new content rather than optimization.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2012-06-07-from-software-having-a-tough-time-porting-dark-souls-to-pc-frame-rate-issues-remain |title=From Software "having a tough time" porting Dark Souls to PC, frame rate issues remain |first=Fred |last=Dutton |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |date=June 7, 2012 |accessdate=October 14, 2013}}</ref> Re-branded as the ''Prepare To Die Edition'', it came out in August 2012 and featured new content, including bosses, enemies, equipment, and NPCs.<ref name="gamingbolt">{{cite web |url=http://gamingbolt.com/dark-souls-prepare-to-die-edition-coming-to-pc-in-august |title=Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition coming to PC in August « GamingBolt.com: Video Game News, Reviews, Previews and Blog |publisher=Gamingbolt.com |date= |accessdate=December 8, 2012}}</ref> The new content, titled "''Artorias of the Abyss''", was released for consoles in October 2012 in the form of DLC.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vg247.com/2012/05/31/dark-souls-pc-coming-to-steam-consoles-to-get-pc-content/ |title=Dark Souls PC coming to Steam, consoles to get PC content |last=Cullen |first=Johnny |date=May 31, 2012 |publisher=VG247 |accessdate=May 31, 2012}}</ref> Soon after, it was announced that ''Dark Souls'' for PC would use [[Games for Windows – Live]] for online play and DRM, spurring fan backlash.<ref>{{cite web |last=Makuch |first=Eddie |title=Gamers rallying against Dark Souls PC using Games for Windows Live |url=http://uk.gamespot.com/news/gamers-rallying-against-dark-souls-pc-using-games-for-windows-live-6371507 |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=April 16, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420174732/http://uk.gamespot.com/news/gamers-rallying-against-dark-souls-pc-using-games-for-windows-live-6371507 |archivedate=April 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=}}</ref>
The PC version was released on August 23, 2012. A user-created [[Mod (video gaming)|mod]] to circumvent the resolution cap, named ''DSFix'', appeared shortly after release.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/dark-souls/1225853p1.html |title=Modder Purportedly Fixes Dark Souls PC Resolution Limitations in 23 Minutes |website=GameSpy.com}}</ref> ''DSFix'' was later extended to become an unofficial [[fan-made patch]] which additionally allowed graphical improvements, raising the [[framerate]] cap to 60, and allowing the installation of custom texture mods.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamestar.de/spiele/dark-souls-prepare-to-die-edition/news/dark_souls_prepare_to_die_edition,48018,3005061.html |title=Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition - Fans bringen das Spiel auf 60FPS |quote=''Die PC-Version des Action-Rollenspiels Dark Souls plagen ein paar Macken. Die fleißige Community hat sich diesen angenommen und einen Patch veröffentlicht, der die Auflösung erhöht und den Framelimiter aushebelt.'' |first=Maximilian |last=Walter |publisher=[[GameStar]] |date=September 18, 2012 |accessdate=October 12, 2013 |language=german}}</ref>
On December 15, 2014, [[Games for Windows – Live]] was removed from the Steam version and replaced by [[Steamworks]]. The ability to transfer both achievements and save data was provided.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://steamcommunity.com/games/211420/announcements/detail/206368522048405952? |title=Dark Souls™ Prepare To Die Edition update to replace the Games for Windows Live functionality with Steamworks is now live |date=December 15, 2014 |accessdate=December 15, 2014 |website=SteamCommunity.com |publisher=shoupinou |last=Grabit |first=Anthony}}</ref> In April 2016, ''Dark Souls'' became available on [[Xbox One]] via [[backward compatibility]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/2/16/11015920/dark-souls-xbox-one-backwards-compatible-dark-souls-3-season-pass |title=Dark Souls Getting Xbox One Compatibility, Free with Dark Souls 3 Pre-Order |last=Frank |first=Allegra |date=February 16, 2016 |website=Polygon|access-date=October 5, 2016}}</ref>
